item.title: A week with Google Chrome
item.description:
nikf:

In the five years that Iâ€™ve used a Mac, Iâ€™ve had two browsers of choice: Camino, and then with Safari 3â€™s arrival Safari. I know that folks swear by Firefox, but I donâ€™t - and typically find myself swearing at Firefox. Whilst the Mozilla folks have done a fine job of making it look like a Mac app, it never seems for feel and behave like a Mac application. Part of my Safari preference is that I also have a teeny bit of a crush for WebKit, the engine that powers Safari with its CSS animations and long-supported (much clichÃ©d) rounded corners.

In a quick trawl through my Applications folder last weekend, I happened to come across a rather old Chrome OS X Developer Preview that Iâ€™d downloaded and promptly forgotten about. Purely out of curiosity I ran it, made sure it was up to date, and started using it.

I havenâ€™t stopped since.

Some Observations

  1. Itâ€™s fast. Lightning fast - I thought Safari was snappy (and compared to Firefox and Camino, it is) but Chrome is screaming in comparison.
  2. Top tabs - I was probably in the minority to mourn their demise in the final Safari 4 release, but itâ€™s great to have them back. The behaviour of Chromeâ€™s â€œOpen in New Tabâ€ option is also fantastic: when opening links in a new tab, the tab opens alongside the existing tab youâ€™re working in. Safari adds tabs after the right-most tab, whereas Chromeâ€™s option groups the links together, easily allowing you to return to your original tab.
  3. Itâ€™s super-stable - itâ€™s not crashed or hung on me in a week - and itâ€™s still not entered Beta. Take that, Safari.
  4. The combined search / address field - I find myself still hitting Tab, expecting it to focus a search box, but another few days use should cure that.
  5. Itâ€™s WebKit - enough said.

The bit where I whinge about some minor issue

Whilst Chrome looks and feels like a Mac application, thereâ€™s one striking annoyance that irritates me: the behaviour when you click on a Folder in the Bookmark bar. In any other browser, it behaves as an OS X menu should. That is, no matter where you click the item, the menu should appear in a fixed location, below the menu item in question. OS Xâ€™s default contextual menus appear directly below and to the right of the area you click.

As it stands right now - and shown in the above comparison - Chromeâ€™s bookmark folders behave like a contextual menu (despite also having their own contextual menus), and itâ€™s driving me a little crazy. Yes, Chrome remains in Pre-Beta - and these things can change - but itâ€™s details like this that make or break whether an application feels like a Mac application. Never mind if an appâ€™s got aqua buttons, a sexy HUD or any other aesthetic beauty. Itâ€™s all about how an application behaves.

If youâ€™re wanting to give Chrome a go, itâ€™s available from the Chrome Developer Channel. Itâ€™s still pre-beta, however in my experience it seems to be more relating to its feature-incomplete state than anything else. Iâ€™ve been using the Chrome Preview non-stop for the past week, and youâ€™ll have to pry it out of my cold, dead hands.
